meanings.definition: To force or trick (someone) into joining a ship, typically as a sailor, by drugging or kidnapping them.
meanings.sent1: The pirates shanghaied the unsuspecting sailors onto their ship.
meanings.sent2: He was shanghaied by the crew and woke up at sea, confused.
meanings.sent3: The captain jokingly threatened to shanghaied the crew if they didn't work harder.
meanings.sent4: The idea of being shanghaied into a life at sea terrified him.
meanings.sent5: The old sailor's tale of being shanghaied haunted the young recruits.

meanings.definition: To coerce or deceive (someone) into doing something against their will.
meanings.sent1: The con artist shanghaied the elderly couple into giving him their savings.
meanings.sent2: She felt shanghaied into attending the party she didn't want to go to.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kids shanghaied their friend into playing a prank on the teacher.
meanings.sent4: The manipulative politician shanghaied the public into believing his lies.
meanings.sent5: The persuasive salesman shanghaied the customers into buying unnecessary products.
